resources.string:
Jacobean building in the south-east London suburb of Charlton. 

Built in 1612 during the reign of James I for his son Prince Henry's tutor Sir Adam Newton. Presumed to have been designed by John Thorpe.

Neoclassical building on the bank of the River Thames in central London. 

Built in 1776 by Sir Williams Chambers, and extended in Victorian times with east and west wings.

Michelin starred restaurant in the Mayfair area of central London. 

The restaurant is run by Will Smith and Anthony Demetre, and serves modern, sophisticated but accessible fayre.

Riverside pub on the south bank of the River Thames. 

Dwarfed by the Tate Modern building behind it, this charming pub has wonderful views towards St Paul's Catherdral.

95-storey skyscraper situated next to London Bridge train and tube station in central London. 

Colloquially known as The Eye of Mordor, also known for pretending to be a Christmas tree during the festive season.

The building contains seven storeys worth of goods and was built in 1864.

Shopping centre built next to St. Paul's Cathedral in The City. 

The centre's selection of shops is rather small but it features a beautifully designed roof terrace with stunning views towards The Shard and St Paul's.

World War II bombed and ruined church in The City. 

Built in 1100 with additions in 1391 and repairs in 1631. Also damaged by fire during The Great Fire of 1666. Sir Christopher Wren added a steeple and tower at the end of the 17th century.
